instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> blinking green light
threads.message:
Have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with a strange issue of not powering up from apple a/c adapter but powers up fine each time with programmable power supply.

Original problem was F4260 was blown from minor liquid damage on dc jack, replaced both and boots fine each time on programmable power supply but green light just blinks with no fan spin when using a normal charger.

What could cause this?? I have tried multiple dc jacks as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> blinking green light
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage with charger connected? Verify the area around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> for possible liquid contact and verify current sensing resistors on that area!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> blinking green light
threads.message:
Original charger detects leakage and do not power up the board.
Usually <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> issue.
Post exact value for <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR>/86 and <RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR>/81, measured onboard (ohm scale).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> blinking green light
